grounding: Demonstrating how race is socially constructed has been a core sociological objective, yet many individuals continue to hold essentialist and other concepts of what races are and how to account for group differences. These conceptualizations have crucial consequences for intergroup attitudes, support for social policies, and structures of inequality, all of which are key sociological concerns; yet much of the research in this area has emerged outside of sociology. Our review of this interdisciplinary scholarship describes the range of views people hold, the attitudes and behaviors associated with them, and what factors contribute to these views. We focus primarily on essentialism and constructivism, although we describe the greater variety of beliefs beyond this dichotomy, as well as fluidity in how people use these concepts. We conclude by presenting research on strategies for reducing essentialist belief systems and identifying key areas for future research.
generated_text: This paper explores the contrasting conceptualizations of race through the lenses of essentialism and constructivism. Essentialist perspectives posit that race is a fixed, biologically determined category, underpinned by inherent and unchanging characteristics. In contrast, constructivist views argue that race is a socially constructed concept, shaped by historical, cultural, and political contexts. The paper reviews empirical studies and theoretical frameworks that highlight the implications of these differing beliefs on social attitudes, policies, and individual identities. By examining the nuances and intersections of essentialist and constructivist paradigms, this research aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of how racial concepts are formed and perpetuated in contemporary society.
